In the most strictest sense, Gravity is not a force of attraction between two bodies of mass. For one, that would be more related to electromagnetic force due to like or different charges causing them to attract. Such Formula for this is very very similar to Newtons Law of Graviation. In the most strictest sense however, gravity is the effect that a body of mass has on the universe, IE spacetime. The gravitational constant is the universal constant that a body of mass has on the universe, or rather how much it stretches it. For example if you have a blanket with a grid lined pattern all around it, with all of it being equal distance. Introducing a mass or a pull on the blanket will cause the distance between the fibers to stretch which is why in black holes, the mass of it causes time to slow and space to expand. Similarly, if you do this with a blanket, such similar effect will happen visually. There is always a force acting on the universe if a body has mass which is called gravity. However, in the most relaxed sense, gravity is a cause of the mass of the planet along side the centripetal force that the earth exerts. What Is Gravity?
1) In General relativity Gravity is an illusion of our circumstance.

Gravity doesn't really exist, only space and time exists and their combined curving gives us the illusion of a gravity force, when no such force exists.
Falling things don't fall, we only see them fall because we live in a curved spacetime but our senses doesn't know that, and interpret our spacetime as a flat one.

When we leave an object to "fall" in zero G it doesn't go anywhere because there are no forces acting on it neither before or after we let it go.
When we leave an object to "fall" in a curved spacetime, it still doesn't go anywhere for the same reason, but since the object ages in a different rate than the rest of the world - that difference in their relation of their aging will make the object and the world intersect themselves at some point in a spacetime diagram even tho the "falling" object, never really moved in space (never really fell anywhere).

Simply, the object in free fall, is momentarily an inertial reference frame (wich means that its a reference frame that doesn't move in space or doesn't accelerate in it), it will age in a straight line while everything else will not ( everything esle that's not an inertial reference frame will age in a curved line (they will age more slowly) (that straight line is also called a geodesic btw)). That aging in a straight line in a spacetime diagram, makes US see this aging (this movement in Time) as an apparent movement in space. In Einstein's view of the world, it's the rest of the world that "rushed up" and hit the Apple.

(and by "up" I don't mean literally up of course)

2) In Quantum Mechanics we simply don't know yet!

(Cont'd) This is stronger than France's pull on you, and so you get pulled towards the other side of the earth. (However, France's pull on you makes you not fall as fast.)

The same thing would happen if you were near the crust directly under Texas, Thailand, or anywhere else. You'd be pulled towards the opposite side of the Earth. The net affect, is that it is as if the (non-existent) core is pulling on you. So, if you were inside the Earth, under France, you'd be telling those French good-bye.

Think of it this way: imagine you are on the inside of this hollow Earth, right next to the crust under, say, France (for example). Now, the crust near you (i.e. France) is pulling you the strongest, so you think that you would be pulled towards the crust. Now, the crust exactly opposite you (under New Zealand) is far away, so you think that it's gravitational pull is very weak. That's true, but the entire WORLD (minus France) is also pulling you in that direction, so it adds up. (Cont'd)

You wouldn't fall towards the crust if you were on the inside - remember, the crust on the opposite side of the earth is also pulling you. (While the crust near you is stronger than other parts of the crust, there is a lot of crust that is not near you. It turns out that these cancel out, and you fall towards the center of the Earth. (Of course, once you REACH the center, inertia flings you to the opposite side of the Earth... I think that takes around 40 mins.))

Gravity is caused by mass, not momentum. However it is not the mass we are familiar with in every day life, so-called rest mass, but total mass that includes a contribution from the energy the object possess, famously given by E = mc^2. A photon has only energy-based mass, and no rest mass. But I don't have to be moving relative to the earth, with some momentum, to experience its gravity.

The reason is that within our current understanding of physics, the energy required to accellerate something with non-zero mass to exactly the speed of light is infinite. The only leeway is if actual photons were not travelling at the speed of light, just approaching it - but to my knowledge no experiment has suggested this.

As for gravity, yes - one useful definition of any force is a rate of change of momentum. Though I'd just point out 'work' is defined in dynamics as force x distance.

Same with light, when it passes nearby the object, it follows the bending and thus make a curve.

A mass has a radius of x meters.  The closest you could be to the center of that mass is x meters.  If your distance from the center were 10x, then the gravitational pull that the mass exerts on you is identical regardless of the radius of the mass itself.  Now if you compressed that same mass into something dense enough to create a black hole, the force on that object 10x away is the same, but you can now get much closer than x meters from the center.  I hope I havent confused you!

Continued more!

Since the gravitational force between objects increases as you get closer to the center, you could now reach the point where the acceleration due to that force reaches the speed of light (in this case, pretty much right at the surface of the pea-sized earth).  On the same token, if you spread the mass of a black hole out, the gravitational pull is identical to what it was before for objects that do not fall within the spread out radius.  Ive got one more to summarize!

Continued...  If you were to take the entire mass of the Earth, and compress it to the size of a pea, it would become a black hole, yet the moon and all the satellites orbiting the Earth would orbit in the exact same way they do today because the force of gravity is measured using the distance to the center of the Earth and assumes the entire mass is concentrated at the center.  That doesn't change.  What DOES change is the fact that you would now be able to get alot closer to the center.

A black hole is simply a lot of mass compacted densely into a small space; so dense that there exists a spherical plane in space outside the mass and surrounding the mass where the acceleration due to gravity is equal to the speed of light.  When the force of g is calculated, the distance used between masses is the distance to the center, so for all intents and purposes we assume that all the mass is concentrated at the center even though the closest we could actually get is equal to the radius

Everything exerts a gravitational force. You don't feel the force for small things because they exert a tiny force. In fact m in E=mc^2 is m=m0/sqroot(1-v^2/c^2) where m0 is the rest mass, c is the speed of light and v is the speed of the object. As you can see from this formula, only speeds approaching c will change m significantly. So if the rest mass of your book is 3Kg and it falls at the speed of 25m/s, its m would be 3.000003125kg.
